Package org.firstinspires.ftc.teamcode.Subsystems.Vision.DetectMarker

Class DetectMarkerPipeline

java.lang.Object
org.openftc.easyopencv.OpenCvPipeline
org.firstinspires.ftc.teamcode.Subsystems.Vision.DetectMarker.DetectMarkerPipeline
public class DetectMarkerPipeline
extends org.openftc.easyopencv.OpenCvPipeline
This pipeline detects where the marker is.

It does this by splitting the camera input into 3 parts, the Left, Middle, and Right. It checks each part for a custom marker (which is set to be green in the code), or some blue or red tape, dependant on the alliance color.

See Also:
OpenCvPipeline, Vision

  • Method Details

    • processFrame

      public org.opencv.core.Mat processFrame​(org.opencv.core.Mat input)
      This method detects where the marker is.

      It does this by splitting the camera input into left, right, and middle rectangles, these rectangles need to be calibrated. Combined, they do not have to encompass the whole camera input, they probably will only check a small part of it. We then assume the alliance color is either (255, 0, 0) or (0, 0, 255), we get the info when the object is instantiated (allianceColor), and that the marker color is (0, 255, 0), which is a bright green (Scalar's are used for colors). We compare the marker color with the alliance color on each of the rectangles, if the marker color is on none or multiple of them, it is marked as MarkerLocation.NOT_FOUND, if otherwise, the respective Location it is in is returned via a MarkerLocation variable called markerLocation

      Specified by:
      processFrame in class org.openftc.easyopencv.OpenCvPipeline
      Parameters:
      input - A Mask (the class is called Mat)
      Returns:
      The marker location
      See Also:
      allianceColor, Mat, Scalar, MarkerLocation

    • getMarkerLocation

      public MarkerLocation getMarkerLocation()

      Returns:
